T1_Agential_Epiphenomenalist.label: Epiphenomenalist
T1_Agential_Epiphenomenalist.description:
Mental events have no causal power; Huxley, Jackson.

This view holds that your thoughts, intentions, and feelings don’t actually cause your actions; instead, they are like byproducts of underlying physical or neural processes. In other words, you may feel like you’re acting intentionally, but according to this position, your mind is along for the ride rather than steering the behavior. Philosophers such as Thomas Huxley and Frank Jackson have explored this idea to question how much agency and mental causation we really possess.

T2_Agential_Hierarchical_Compatibilist.label: Hierarchical Compatibilist
T2_Agential_Hierarchical_Compatibilist.description: Frankfurt, Watson — free when acting on desires one endorses.

T3_Agential_Soft_Compatibilist.label: Soft Compatibilist / Humean about Freedom
T3_Agential_Soft_Compatibilist.description: Hume, Dennett — freedom as acting according to one’s own motives.

T4_Agential_Hard_Determinist.label: Hard Determinist
T4_Agential_Hard_Determinist.description: Spinoza, d’Holbach — no freedom, just causal necessity.

T5_Agential_Substance_Dualist.label: Substance Dualist / Cartesian Agent
T5_Agential_Substance_Dualist.description: Descartes, Swinburne — immaterial soul enables freedom.

T6_Agential_Agent_Causal_Libertarian.label: Agent-Causal Libertarian
T6_Agential_Agent_Causal_Libertarian.description: Reid, Chisholm, O’Connor — consciousness itself has causal power.

T7_Agential_Indeterministic_Libertarian.label: Indeterministic Libertarian
T7_Agential_Indeterministic_Libertarian.description: Eccles, Kane — quantum randomness introduces openness in action.

T8_Agential_Emergentist.label: Emergentist about Agency
T8_Agential_Emergentist.description: Non-reductive physicalism; agency as creative advance - Bergson, Whitehead

T9_Agential_Behaviorist.label: Behaviorist
T9_Agential_Behaviorist.description: Skinner, Ryle — actions are just caused behaviors, no genuine reasons.

T10_Agential_Neurophysical_Reductionist.label: Neurophysical Reductionist
T10_Agential_Neurophysical_Reductionist.description: Churchlands — reasons are brain states, physical explanation only.

T11_Agential_Pragmatist_Reasons.label: Pragmatist about Reasons
T11_Agential_Pragmatist_Reasons.description: Dewey, Brandom — reasons are social function; no intrinsic force.

T12_Agential_Kantian_Constitutivist.label: Kantian Constitutivist
T12_Agential_Kantian_Constitutivist.description: Korsgaard — authority of reasons derives from rational nature itself.

T13_Agential_Hegelian_Recognition.label: Hegelian Recognition Theorist
T13_Agential_Hegelian_Recognition.description: Hegel, contemporary recognition ethics — authority depends on social recognition.

T14_Agential_Moral_Realist.label: Moral Realist / Natural Law Theorist
T14_Agential_Moral_Realist.description: Aquinas, Foot, Parfit — moral facts or natural law ground universal reason.

T15_Agential_Kantian_Rationalist.label: Kantian Rationalist
T15_Agential_Kantian_Rationalist.description: Kant, Korsgaard — structure of practical reason grounds universality.

T16_Agential_Constitutive_Kantian.label: Constitutive Kantian
T16_Agential_Constitutive_Kantian.description: Korsgaard — categorical normativity emerges from agency itself.

T17_Agential_Cultural_Relativist.label: Cultural Relativist
T17_Agential_Cultural_Relativist.description: Boas, Benedict, Harman — reasons are relative to culture.

T18_Agential_Wittgensteinian_Conventiona.label: Wittgensteinian Conventionalist
T18_Agential_Wittgensteinian_Conventiona.description: Winch, Anscombe-influenced readings — reasons grounded in language/concepts.

T19_Agential_Pragmatist_Norms.label: Pragmatist about Norms
T19_Agential_Pragmatist_Norms.description: Dewey, Brandom — reasons relative to social practices.

T20_Agential_Humean_Instrumentalist.label: Humean Instrumentalist
T20_Agential_Humean_Instrumentalist.description: Hume, Williams — personal reasons grounded in desire/self-interest.

T21_Agential_Nietzschean_Perspectivalist.label: Nietzschean Perspectivalist
T21_Agential_Nietzschean_Perspectivalist.description: Nietzsche — personal reasons grounded in power/will.

T22_Agential_Existentialist.label: Existentialist
T22_Agential_Existentialist.description: Sartre, Beauvoir — personal reasons arise from completely open choice.

T23_Agential_Moral_Cognitivist.label: Moral Cognitivist / Realist
T23_Agential_Moral_Cognitivist.description: Moore, Ross, Shafer-Landau — discovering moral truth.

T24_Agential_Constructivist.label: Constructivist
T24_Agential_Constructivist.description: Rawls, Scanlon — moral norms are created, not discovered.

T25_Agential_Noncognitivist.label: Noncognitivist / Expressivist
T25_Agential_Noncognitivist.description: Ayer, Blackburn, Gibbard — moral language expresses attitudes, not truth.

T26_Agential_Intellectualist.label: Intellectualist
T26_Agential_Intellectualist.description: Socrates, Plato — acting well depends on knowing what is right.

T27_Agential_Sentimentalist.label: Sentimentalist
T27_Agential_Sentimentalist.description: Hume, Hutcheson, Slote — acting well depends on feeling/caring rightly.

T28_Agential_Virtue_Ethicist.label: Virtue Ethicist
T28_Agential_Virtue_Ethicist.description: Aristotle, MacIntyre, Foot — acting well requires both knowledge and caring.

T1_Normative_Nihilist.label: Normative Nihilist
T1_Normative_Nihilist.description: Denies that 'should' makes sense; moral or evaluative talk is empty.

T2_Normative_Reasons_Fundamentalist.label: Reasons Fundamentalist
T2_Normative_Reasons_Fundamentalist.description: Parfit, Scanlon — rationality is objective, morality constructed.

T3_Normative_Aesthetic_Realist.label: Aesthetic Realist / Moral Anti-Realist
T3_Normative_Aesthetic_Realist.description: Evaluative judgments in aesthetic domain have real content, moral judgments may not.

T4_Normative_Normative_Contextualist.label: Normative Contextualist
T4_Normative_Normative_Contextualist.description: Dancy, particularists — norms are real but content depends on situation and practice.

T5_Normative_Hybrid_Expressivist.label: Hybrid Expressivist
T5_Normative_Hybrid_Expressivist.description: Ridge — expressions answer to normative facts.

T6_Normative_Quasi_Realist.label: Quasi-Realist
T6_Normative_Quasi_Realist.description: Blackburn — norms gain truth through internal consistency/coherence.

T7_Normative_Functionalist_Expressivist.label: Functionalist Expressivist
T7_Normative_Functionalist_Expressivist.description: Gibbard — norms coordinate social life; appropriateness comes from social function.

T8_Normative_Kantian_Expressivist.label: Kantian Expressivist / Constructivist
T8_Normative_Kantian_Expressivist.description: Normative attitudes are constrained by rational principles.

T9_Normative_Emotivist.label: Emotivist
T9_Normative_Emotivist.description: Ayer, Stevenson — moral language is pure expression of emotion.

T10_Normative_Desire_Satisfaction_Theori.label: Desire-Satisfaction Theorist
T10_Normative_Desire_Satisfaction_Theori.description: Ideal desire theories — norms grounded in desires or preferences.

T11_Normative_Utilitarian_Welfarist.label: Utilitarian / Welfarist
T11_Normative_Utilitarian_Welfarist.description: Bentham, Mill, Singer — norms grounded in pleasure or well-being.

T12_Normative_Naturalistic_Virtue_Ethici.label: Naturalistic Virtue Ethicist
T12_Normative_Naturalistic_Virtue_Ethici.description: Foot, Hursthouse — norms grounded in flourishing or functional completion.

T13_Normative_Evolutionary_Naturalist.label: Evolutionary Naturalist / Debunker
T13_Normative_Evolutionary_Naturalist.description: Street, Joyce — evolved dispositions explain normative facts.

T14_Normative_Intuitionist.label: Intuitionist
T14_Normative_Intuitionist.description: Moore, Ross, Audi — direct apprehension of sui generis normative facts.

T15_Normative_Rationalist_Moral_Realist.label: Rationalist Moral Realist
T15_Normative_Rationalist_Moral_Realist.description: Kant, Sidgwick, Parfit — normative truths known via reason and reflection.

T16_Normative_Perceptual_Moral_Realist.label: Perceptual Moral Realist
T16_Normative_Perceptual_Moral_Realist.description: McDowell, Dancy — moral perception through trained sensitivity.

T17_Normative_Kantian_Constructivist.label: Kantian Constructivist
T17_Normative_Kantian_Constructivist.description: Rawls, Korsgaard, Scanlon — framework valid via rational coherence.

T18_Normative_Contractualist.label: Contractualist
T18_Normative_Contractualist.description: Scanlon, Gauthier — framework validated by social agreement and mutual advantage.

T19_Normative_Pragmatist_Normativity.label: Pragmatist about Normativity
T19_Normative_Pragmatist_Normativity.description: Dewey, Rorty — practical success and adaptive value justify norms.

T20_Normative_Normative_Subjectivist.label: Normative Subjectivist
T20_Normative_Normative_Subjectivist.description: Pure relativism; no framework gives objective validity.

T21_Normative_Humean_Internalist.label: Humean Internalist
T21_Normative_Humean_Internalist.description: Williams — obligation motivates only if it aligns with agent’s desires.

T22_Normative_Kantian_Internalist.label: Kantian Internalist
T22_Normative_Kantian_Internalist.description: Rational agents are necessarily motivated by moral law.

T24_Normative_Aristotelian_Thomist_Exter.label: Aristotelian / Thomist Externalist
T24_Normative_Aristotelian_Thomist_Exter.description: Aquinas — obligation grounded in natural law.

T25_Normative_Non_Naturalist_Realist.label: Non-Naturalist Realist
T25_Normative_Non_Naturalist_Realist.description: Parfit, Shafer-Landau — norms exist independently of motivation.

T1_Modal_Necessitarian.label: Necessitarian
T1_Modal_Necessitarian.description: Spinoza, Leibniz — only this world is possible; everything necessary.

T2_Modal_Eliminativist.label: Modal Eliminativist
T2_Modal_Eliminativist.description: Quine — modality is dubious metaphysics; no objective possibility.

T3_Modal_Conceptual_Idealist.label: Conceptual Idealist about Modality
T3_Modal_Conceptual_Idealist.description: Modal structure arises from linguistic-conceptual frameworks.

T4_Modal_Transcendental_Idealist.label: Transcendental Idealist about Modality
T4_Modal_Transcendental_Idealist.description: Kant — modality is a category of understanding.

T5_Modal_Conventionalist.label: Conventionalist about Logic
T5_Modal_Conventionalist.description: Carnap, Ayer — logical truths are analytic, based on meanings and conventions.

T6_Modal_Mind_Independent_Grounding.label: Mind-Independent Grounding
T6_Modal_Mind_Independent_Grounding.description: Logical truths exist independently of human minds or conventions, though not necessarily as abstract objects. Truths are objective features of reality rather than merely conceptual.

T7_Modal_Kantian_Logic.label: Kantian about Logic
T7_Modal_Kantian_Logic.description: Necessity arises from the structure of thought.

T9_Modal_Conceptual_Relativist.label: Conceptual Relativist
T9_Modal_Conceptual_Relativist.description: Conceptual necessities can be fixed by frameworks or revisable/engineerable.

T10_Modal_Conceptual_Engineer.label: Conceptual Engineer
T10_Modal_Conceptual_Engineer.description: Modal norms can be deliberately reformed within conceptual frameworks.

T11_Modal_Epistemic_Reductionist.label: Humean about Laws
T11_Modal_Epistemic_Reductionist.description: Laws of nature are regularities, not strictly necessary; possibility is grounded in the patterns of events, not metaphysical necessity.

T12_Modal_Modal_Realist.label: Modal Realist
T12_Modal_Modal_Realist.description: David Lewis — alternative possibilities exist as concrete worlds.

T13_Modal_Linguistic_Ersatzist.label: Linguistic Ersatzist
T13_Modal_Linguistic_Ersatzist.description: Adams, Plantinga — abstract possibilities as maximally consistent propositions.

T14_Modal_Combinatorial_Theorist.label: Combinatorial Theorist
T14_Modal_Combinatorial_Theorist.description: Armstrong, Forrest — abstract possibilities as states of affairs.

T15_Modal_Abstract_Modal_Realist.label: Abstract Modal Realist
T15_Modal_Abstract_Modal_Realist.description: Plantinga — primitive possibilia exist as abstract entities.

T17_Modal_Modal_Fictionalist.label: Modal Fictionalist
T17_Modal_Modal_Fictionalist.description: Rosen — modality treated as useful fiction.

T18_Modal_Intrinsic_Dispositionalist.label: Intrinsic Dispositionalist
T18_Modal_Intrinsic_Dispositionalist.description: Molnar, Mumford — possibilities grounded in intrinsic powers of things.

T19_Modal_Relational_Dispositionalist.label: Relational Dispositionalist
T19_Modal_Relational_Dispositionalist.description: Cartwright, Heil — possibilities grounded in relations among things.

T20_Modal_Semantic_Anti_Essentialist.label: Semantic Anti-Essentialist
T20_Modal_Semantic_Anti_Essentialist.description: Vagueness in essence due to language/semantics.

T21_Modal_Ontological_Anti_Essentialist.label: Ontological Anti-Essentialist
T21_Modal_Ontological_Anti_Essentialist.description: Vagueness in essence due to reality/ontology itself.

T22_Modal_Origin_Essentialist.label: Origin Essentialist
T22_Modal_Origin_Essentialist.description: Identity across possibilities grounded in same parents/body.

T23_Modal_Continuity_Theorist.label: Continuity Theorist
T23_Modal_Continuity_Theorist.description: Identity across possibilities grounded in psychological/physical continuity.

T24_Modal_Haecceitist.label: Haecceitist
T24_Modal_Haecceitist.description: Identity across possibilities grounded in primitive thisness.

T27_Modal_Social_Essentialist.label: Social Essentialist
T27_Modal_Social_Essentialist.description: Social essences grounded in recognition and roles.

T28_Modal_Relational_Essentialist.label: Relational Essentialist
T28_Modal_Relational_Essentialist.description: Social essences grounded in relational networks.

T1_Experiential_Radical_Skeptic.label: Radical Skeptic / Solipsist of the Present Moment
T1_Experiential_Radical_Skeptic.description: Doubts even immediate experience; no sensation is trusted.

T2_Experiential_Monist.label: Monist
T2_Experiential_Monist.description: Reality is fundamentally one; all experience unified. (Parmenides, Spinoza)

T3_Experiential_Heraclitean.label: Heraclitean
T3_Experiential_Heraclitean.description: Pure flux; all things unique and constantly changing.

T4_Experiential_Bundle_Theorist.label: Bundle Theorist
T4_Experiential_Bundle_Theorist.description: Objects are just bundles of properties; distinctions may be confused. (Hume)

T5_Experiential_Phenomenalist.label: Phenomenalist
T5_Experiential_Phenomenalist.description: Principally unknowable; reality apprehended through perception. (Berkeley, early Carnap)

T6_Experiential_Strong_Phenomenalist.label: Strong Phenomenalist
T6_Experiential_Strong_Phenomenalist.description: Belief that things only exist when perceived (esse est percipi).

T7_Experiential_Verificationist.label: Verificationist / Logical Positivist
T7_Experiential_Verificationist.description: Claims that are meaningless if not empirically verifiable.

T8_Experiential_Kantian.label: Kantian
T8_Experiential_Kantian.description: Patterns or recurring kinds constrained by categories structuring experience.

T9_Experiential_Radical_Conventionalist.label: Radical Conventionalist / Nominalist
T9_Experiential_Radical_Conventionalist.description: Recurring patterns are arbitrary, imposed by the mind.

T10_Experiential_Platonist.label: Platonist about Universals
T10_Experiential_Platonist.description: Recurring kinds exist independently of individual instances.

T11_Experiential_Aristotelian_Realist.label: Aristotelian Realist
T11_Experiential_Aristotelian_Realist.description: Recurring kinds exist within individual instances.

T12_Experiential_Resemblance_Nominalist.label: Resemblance Nominalist
T12_Experiential_Resemblance_Nominalist.description: Recurring kinds do not exist independently; objects just resemble each other.

T13_Experiential_Transcendental_Idealist.label: Transcendental Idealist
T13_Experiential_Transcendental_Idealist.description: Persists things exist interactively with the mind. (Kant)

T14_Experiential_Solipsist.label: Solipsist
T14_Experiential_Solipsist.description: Persistent things dependent on my mind alone.

T15_Experiential_Idealist.label: Idealist
T15_Experiential_Idealist.description: Persistent things dependent on minds in general. (Berkeley, Hegel)

T16_Experiential_Social_Constructionist.label: Social Constructionist
T16_Experiential_Social_Constructionist.description: Persistent things dependent on collective minds or social frameworks.

T17_Experiential_Direct_Naive_Realist.label: Direct / Naive Realist
T17_Experiential_Direct_Naive_Realist.description: Belief in direct access to persisting things; no mediation by representations.

T18_Experiential_Direct_Realist.label: Direct Realist
T18_Experiential_Direct_Realist.description: Perception as it really is, unmediated by representation.

T19_Experiential_Scientific_Realist.label: Scientific / Critical Realist
T19_Experiential_Scientific_Realist.description: Knowledge of things independent of representations is possible.

T20_Experiential_Kantian_Thing_in_Itself.label: Kantian — things-in-themselves unknowable
T20_Experiential_Kantian_Thing_in_Itself.description: Reality exists beyond appearances but is inaccessible.

T21_Experiential_Pragmatist.label: Pragmatist
T21_Experiential_Pragmatist.description: Focuses on what works in experience rather than what is ultimately real; truth is understood in terms of practical consequences.
